Such ingenuity had little appeal for the tough Macedonian officers They knew,  as well as Alexander knew himself,  that Alexander was as much a man as any of them.  They were frightened by the growing signs of megalomania in the young man.  And pros^nesis — the really concrete issue — was something which,  in a firm and obstinate way,  they were not prepared to practise.  Callisthenes summed up the atmosphere clearly enough ; he knew that the project had no chance whatever of success.  To speak of his »amazing volte - face<0^ is to create a difficulty where no difficulty at all exists.  Writing about the » son of Zeus « — and Callisthenes was not alone in this®® — and of »the obeisance of the waves was one thing ; arguing in favour of a policy offensive in itself and certainly doomed to failure wäs another.  To speak against the proposal was to speak on the winning side,  for the senior Macedonian army commanders were still the fundamental support of Alexander's power.  Callisthenes supported their prejudice and,  at the same time,  we may be sure,  he followed his own inclination.  He may have used some of the arguments which Arrian and Q.  Curtius put into his mouth ; he certainly did not use them а1р2.  He had no reason to expect that his attitude would estrange him permanently from Alexander ; but he reckoned without his own indiscretion,  his own osity®^.  He evidently said tacdess things which,  reported in due course to Alexander,  caused great offence.  But for the moment he was on the winning side ; and the proposal to introducepros / gnesis was dropped.
